Lab Testing

Normal Lab Values

  1. Reference ranges vary per institution and are unique to the device utilized for testing
    • -PT 12-14 seconds
    • -PTT 24-36 seconds
    • -ATIII 82-139% (age dependent)
    • -Anti factor Xa 0 u/mL
    • -ACT 90-110 seconds

ECLS Lab Values

  1. Reference ranges vary per institution and are unique to the device utilized for testing
    • -PT <15-16 seconds
    • -PTT 60-90 seconds
    • -ATIII 80-120%
    • -Anti factor Xa 0.3-0.8 u/mL
    • -ACT 180-220 seconds

Download this information - it is good reference material.

Download this resources

Lab Sampling

  1. Coags should be collected from a sampling port prior to heparin infusion (if heparin is infusing into the ECLS circuit)
    • -Prevents sample contamination
  2. It is important to wait 3-4 hrs after heparin drip changes or boluses to send coag labs. It is acceptable to send labs prior to this if checking for under anticoagulation, response to apparent over anticoagulation may not be advisable.
    • -May not reflect steady state of heparin infusion if drawn prior to the recommended wait time.

Remember to want this critical 3-4 period after heparin drop changes or boluses to send coag labs.

Labs

  1. Activated Clotting Time (ACT)
    • -Bedside/point of care test
    • -Measured in seconds
      • Several different devices and activators
        • Micro clot
        • Macro Clot
      • Looks at overall coagulation
        • (Common and Intrinsic pathways)
  1. Prothrombin time (PT)
    • -Extrinsic pathway
    • -Should be normal in presence of heparin
      • If not, treat cause
      • Normalize with FFP administration
    • -Prolonged with dilution and DIC
    • -Will be significantly impacted by rFVIIa administration

Remember the Prothrombin time(PT) should be normal in the presence of heparin.


  1. Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (PTT)
    • -Intrinsic pathway
    • -Impacted directly by heparin and direct thrombin inhibitors
    • -Correlates with antifactor Xa
    • -Also influenced by platelets, fibrinogen, and other clotting factors
